metadata.case_name: The Company (Appellant Employer) v. Workmen (Respondents Nos. 2-48)

facts.text: On August 3, 1953, the Government of West Bengal referred an industrial dispute between the appellant company and its workmen under s. 10 of the Industrial Disputes Act to the second Industrial Tribunal.

On October 6, 1953, during pendency of the reference, workmen surrounded and confined E. L. D'Cruz, acting Works Manager, in factory premises from 9:15 a.m. to 2:15 p.m. over dispute on Puja bonus payment.

On October 6, 1953, same day, workmen went on strike at 9:15 a.m.; D'Cruz called them to resume work; company issued notices at 9:45 a.m. and 10:45 a.m. to resume; workmen refused; company declared lock-out after police arrival; some workmen arrested.
Company served charge-sheets on workmen requiring explanations within 24 hours; workmen submitted explanations; enquiry held; workmen found guilty of gross misconduct meriting dismissal.
On October 31, 1953, company applied under s. 33 of the Act (Cal. Nos. 518, 519, 557 of 1953) to second Industrial Tribunal for permission to dismiss 170 workmen effective October 6, 1953.
Company withdrew cases against large number of workmen; proceedings continued against 67 workmen; one died, two resigned, leaving 64.
Workmen denied offence, receipt of charge-sheets, enquiry; pleaded illegal lock-out, contravention of natural justice.
Tribunal permitted dismissal of three workmen (Subbas Roy, Madhusudhan Rout, Bimal Kumar Ghose); refused for rest due to doubt on identity and complicity.
On January 8, 1954, workmen filed application under s. 33A, allowed on July 2, 1954.
Three appeals to Labour Appellate Tribunal (LAT): two by company against s.33 orders, one by workmen against permission for three dismissals.
On March 29, 1955, LAT dismissed company's s.33 appeal, upheld three dismissals, set aside s.33A order as misconceived and without jurisdiction.

On April 20, 1955, company initiated fresh proceedings: sent registered notices to 64 workmen's registered addresses, affixed notices on notice boards inside and outside premises (remained till June 9, 1955); notices to Nos.2-24 returned unserved.
On April 28, 1955, company informed Labour Commissioner of offences and proposed action.
On May 20, 1955, company wrote to Workers' Union secretary for addresses of unserved workmen; no reply.
Managerial enquiry terminated on June 9, 1955; no pending proceedings under Act; services of 64 workmen terminated on June 22, 1955.

Termination led to industrial dispute; West Bengal Government referred on August 8, 1955, under s.10: whether dismissal of 64 justified, reinstatement, compensation for action and idleness from 1953-10-06, implementation of prior awards.
16 workmen resigned; Haroo Haldar pleaded guilty; proceedings continued against 47 workmen.

Sixth Industrial Tribunal award on June 7, 1956: Nos.2-24 not properly served, reinstate from April 1, 1955 with back wages etc.; Nos.25-48 dismissal justified (identity established, no bias); strike illegal, no compensation pre-1955-03-29 except for Nos.2-24 from 1955-04-01; confirmed prior permission for three dismissals.
Two appeals to LAT: one by Union, one by company.

On September 11, 1956, LAT dismissed company appeal, allowed Union's: doubted D'Cruz evidence (absent in 1954, given in 1955), no other evidence, management decision perverse; set aside IT permission for Nos.25-48.

LAT suo motu amended order on September 28, 1956: set aside IT award confirming discharge of 24 workmen, ordered reinstatement of 24 with back wages from April 1, 1955 to reinstatement; confirmed award otherwise.

legal_issues.text: Whether the Labour Appellate Tribunal could interfere with the managerial enquiry and dismissal, acting as if sitting in appeal.
Whether service of charge-sheets/notices to workmen Nos.2-24 was proper under standing orders and principles of natural justice.
Whether s.33 proceedings operate as res judicata barring fresh enquiry and dismissal.
Whether there was basic error in managerial findings justifying tribunal interference.

petitioner_arguments.text: Appeal to LAT by Union incompetent as no question of law involved.
LAT cannot sit in appeal against managerial enquiry; interference only if want of good faith, victimisation, unfair practice, basic error or natural justice violation.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Indian Iron and Steel Co. Ltd. v. Their Workmen; principles laid down by Supreme Court

petitioner_arguments.text: Service of notices proper: registered post, affixed on notice boards inside/outside per standing orders; efforts made (letter to union, labour commissioner); no natural justice violation.
Fresh enquiry permissible post s.33 refusal; s.33 only prima facie permission, not adjudication; no res judicata.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: s.33 Industrial Disputes Act; Atherton West Co. Ltd. v. Suti Mill Mazdoor Union; Automobile Products of India Ltd. v. Rukmaji Bala

petitioner_arguments.text: No basic error; proceedings against 67/170 after withdrawals; numbers consistent.
Strike illegal (pendency of reference); lock-out justified; no compensation.

respondent_arguments.text: No proper notice/service to Nos.2-24; affixing on notice board insufficient during lock-out; should have sent to union or advertised in newspapers.
No second enquiry possible; s.33 findings (doubt on identity) res judicata.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: Res judicata; s.33 Industrial Disputes Act

respondent_arguments.text: Basic errors in IT award; LAT rightly interfered (e.g., numbers inconsistency: 100-130 confiners, but proceedings against 67/170).
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: Indian Iron and Steel Co. Ltd. v. Their Workmen

respondent_arguments.text: Workmen entitled to compensation from April 1, 1955 to June 6, 1955.

court_reasoning.text: LAT erred by sitting in appeal over managerial enquiry, doubting D'Cruz evidence without basis for perversity; misapprehended proceedings as s.33/s.33A instead of s.10 reference.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Tribunal interferes only on want of good faith, victimisation, unfair practice, basic error, or natural justice violation; none present.

court_reasoning.text: Service proper per standing orders (affixed boards inside/outside, registered post, union letter, labour commissioner informed); workmen could access outer board; no need for more.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Complied with Cl.15; no natural justice infraction.

court_reasoning.text: s.33 is prima facie permission only, not adjudication; no res judicata for subsequent s.10 dispute.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Protects against victimisation during pendency; does not bar fresh enquiry/dismissal.

court_reasoning.text: No basic error; parties proceeded on consistent numbers (67 proceeded, 64 left, etc.); not argued below.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Management judgment on misconduct valid if facts-based, good faith.

court_reasoning.text: Strike illegal; belligerent action; lock-out justified; no compensation entitlement.

holdings.text: Industrial Tribunal/LAT cannot act as court of appeal over managerial enquiry; limited interference grounds not met.
Notice service valid under standing orders; no natural justice violation.
s.33 proceedings do not attract res judicata for s.10 reference.

precedents_cited.case_name: Indian Iron and Steel Co. Ltd. v. Their Workmen
precedents_cited.relevance: Principles governing tribunal interference with managerial enquiry: only on good faith want, victimisation, unfair practice, basic error, natural justice violation.

precedents_cited.case_name: Lakshmi Devi Sugar Mills Ltd. v. Pt. Ram Sarup
precedents_cited.relevance: No interference if fair enquiry, illegal strike, misconduct found without natural justice violation.

precedents_cited.case_name: Buckingham and Carnatic Co. Ltd. v. Its workmen
precedents_cited.relevance: Cited by LAT on evidence principles.

precedents_cited.case_name: Hanuman Jute Mills v. Amin Das
precedents_cited.relevance: No appeal where tribunal examined bona fides, unfair practice, motive in s.33.

precedents_cited.case_name: Atherton West Co. Ltd. v. Suti Mill Mazdoor Union
precedents_cited.relevance: s.33 does not bar industrial dispute post-permission.

precedents_cited.case_name: Automobile Products of India Ltd. v. Rukmaji Bala
precedents_cited.relevance: s.33/22 only for permission, not adjudication; no res judicata.

statutes_cited.name: Industrial Disputes Act, 1947
statutes_cited.relevance: Reference of disputes; permission for dismissal during pendency; special application for contravention; illegal strike notice.

statutes_cited.name: Industrial Disputes (Appellate Tribunal) Act, 1950
statutes_cited.relevance: Permission for dismissal akin to s.33.

statutes_cited.name: Company Standing Orders
statutes_cited.relevance: Defines major misdemeanours (insubordination, illegal strike); mode of notice service (oral, notice board).

outcome.summary: Appeal allowed; LAT orders (Sep 11/28, 1956) and IT award (Jun 7, 1956) as to workmen Nos.2-24 set aside; dismissals of all 47 workmen upheld as justified; no reinstatement or back wages/compensation.
outcome.relief_granted: None to workmen; employer's dismissals affirmed.

key_quotes.text: "Undoubtedly, the management of a concern has power to direct its own internal administration and discipline but the power, is not unlimited and when a dispute arises, Industrial Tribunals have been given the power to see whether the termination of service of a workman is justified and to give appropriate relief. In cases of dismissal or misconduct, the Tribunal does not, however, act as a Court of appeal and substitute its own judgment for that of the management."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Core principle limiting tribunal interference with managerial enquiries (from Indian Iron & Steel case).

key_quotes.text: "It will interfere (i) when there is want of good faith, (ii) when there is victimisation or unfair labour practice, (iii) when the management has been guilty of a basic error or violation of a principle of natural justice, and (iv) when on the materials, the finding is completely baseless or perverse."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Enumerates exhaustive grounds for tribunal intervention.

key_quotes.text: "The purpose of s. 33 of the Act is merely to give or withhold permission and not to adjudicate upon an industrial dispute, any finding under s. 33 would not operate as res judicata."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Clarifies limited scope of s.33, no bar on subsequent disputes.
